Award.AwardTitle: SAVI: Virtual International Institute for Seismic Performance Assessment of Structural Wall Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Structural walls, which are solid concrete walls commonly used in buildings around stairwells and elevators, are used worldwide because they are economical to construct, efficient to separate spaces, and effective in protecting buildings from strong earthquake ground shaking. Unexpected damage that occurred to structural walls in recent earthquakes, e.g., Chile in 2010 and New Zealand in 2011, as well as damage observed in recent laboratory tests in the United States and Japan, suggest that structural engineers have pushed seismic design limits for structural walls beyond a critical boundary. Despite these observations, engineers are increasingly choosing to use structural walls because, historically, structural wall buildings are less likely to collapse in earthquakes and are more likely to limit heavy damage to building contents. Given recent observations, considerable research on the seismic performance and design of structural walls has been initiated or is planned in the United States and around the world. Many of the research needs identified for structural walls require large-scale laboratory testing to validate and calibrate computational models and to develop and refine seismic design recommendations for building codes. Large-scale testing is expensive; therefore, the ability of any one country to address the breadth of issues that have been identified is limited and progress will be slow.

Given the critical research needs for structural walls and the limited resources available to individual countries, this award will facilitate international research collaborations using both in-person meetings and virtual collaboration tools by creating a virtual international institute for the seismic performance assessment of structural wall systems. Through this institute, researchers from Chile, Japan, New Zealand, and the United States, who have a long history of both informal and formal research collaboration, will share research test plans and test data; develop, improve, calibrate, and validate component and system models used for building design; achieve consensus, where possible, on critical performance issues; prepare joint reports, papers, and design recommendations; and develop collaborative new research directions. Institute results will be disseminated by members participating in meetings, workshops, and code committees, by involving earthquake professionals, by developing and distributing educational materials and project results (e.g., data), and by creating a project web site. Mentoring and training of young researchers (students and faculty) will be enhanced through participation in both face-to-face meetings and virtual collaboration with leading researchers and practitioners from around the world. The broader U.S. and international earthquake engineering research community will benefit from joint publications, access to data, and opportunities for enhanced collaboration (in-person and virtual). This award is designated as a Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) award and is co-funded by NSF's Directorate for Engineering and NSF's Office of Integrative and International Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Structural (shear) walls are one of the most widely used forms of building construction used around the world to resist earthquake shaking worldwide. Their widespread use is because of economy of construction, efficiency in separating spaces, and effectiveness in protecting buildings from strong earthquake ground shaking. Unexpected damage to wall buildings in recent earthquakes, e.g., Chile in 2010 and New Zealand in 2011, indicate there are numerous issues that are not adequately addressed by prior studies and in our US building codes, nor in building codes in other countries.

Because of the issues noted in the preceding paragraph, considerable research on wall behavior and design has recently been completed or is ongoing, both in the US and around the world. Many of these issues require some level of large-scale testing to validate and calibrate numerical and computer models and develop and refine design recommendations and code change proposals. Large-scale testing is expensive; therefore, the ability of any one country to address the breadth of issues that have been identified is limited. The NSF SAVI award built on these common needs to improve collaboration through improved communications. The primary objectives of the collaboration will be to speed progress towards developing safer and more resilient societies around the globe by sharing test plans and test data, developing/improving and calibrating/validating component and system computer models, and developing collaborative research proposals to address these issues.

To achieve these goals, three in-person workshops and several face-to-face meetings were held. These 1.5 to 2 day workshops were typically attended by 30 to 45 researchers (faculty, students) and practicing engineers. The workshop agendas included presentations and discussions of ongoing and planned research, discussion of critical issues facing practicing engineers, and opportunities for collaborative research and researcher exchanges. Additional meetings were held at the 16th World Conference on Earthquake Engineering in Santiago, Chile (January 2017) and the 11th US National Conference on Earthquake Engineering (June 2018). Three working groups were formed to work on numerical modeling issues, development of databases, and identify key issues related to addressing more complex issues related to bi-axial loading.

Technology transfer was achieved by: (1) presenting research results at major conferences, (2) publishing peer-reviewed conference and journal papers, (3) creating a website to archive results, and (4) preparing state-of-the art papers on nonlinear macro- and micro-modeling approaches used by researchers and practicing engineers for design and assessment of reinforced concrete buildings. Research collaborations and exchanges were developed to improve assessment of damaged structural walls. A component of this work includes researcher exchanges (sabbaticals).

Critical issues related to the behavior and design of reinforced concrete wall systems were identified at the in-person and a paper summarizing these issues was published in the Bulletin of the a New Zealand Society for Earthquake Engineering, Vol 50, No 4, pp 608-615.

Finally, in additional to the conference papers and journal papers mentioned above, six critical code change proposals were developed and shepherded through American Concrete Institute Committee 318 and were approved for ACI 318-19, Chapter 18 – Earthquake Resistant Structures (ACI 318 is the code that is used to design new buildings). All of these changes are important and required a significant effort to complete, creating a lasting footprint for the group on the ACI 318 code.
